paragraphs.text: Why Charlie Hebdo attack is not about Islam.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Twelve people were massacred in Paris on Wednesday merely for expressing their opinion through art
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Many might not like the art that prompted the carnage
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They may consider it obscene and even an attack on their faith
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But in the 21st, 15th or 57th century - whatever your religion, calendar, or country- there is no excuse or justification for responding to art with murder
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But there is a clear and frightening explanation for this violence, one that demands not merely outrage at the act itself, but at the system that has made it both predictable and inevitable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The problem is that this system is hundreds of years old, implicates most everyone, and has only become more entrenched in the last several decades
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: as the world has become ever more globalised
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Where does the story begin?
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: Quite simply with colonialism
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: It's no mere coincidence that at least two of the Charlie Hebdo attackers are reportedly of Algerian descent and the third from Senegal
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: France's 1830 invasion of Algeria began a 130-year odyssey of murder, expropriation, racism, exploitation and misrule that only ended after a vicious anti-colonial struggle costing well over one million Algerian lives
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "Colonisation brought the genocide of our identity, of our history, of our language, of our traditions" is how President Abdelaziz Bouteflika well described it
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: French rule in sub-Saharan West Africa was even more costly, particularly in the context of the centuries-long slave trade
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Of course
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: as in so many newly independent countries, post-independence Algeria and Senegal were ruled by a government that was tied umbilically to the former coloniser
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: which, however "postcolonial" their official ideology and credentials, became increasing authoritarian and corrupt
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In Algeria, the petroleum-rich FLN state - known as "the pouvoir" because of its all-pervasive power - went so far as to launch a brutal internal war that claimed 100,000 lives in the 1990s with the direct support of the West, all to preserve its absolute grip on power
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Nigeria, another major oil producer, received similar support for its even more ruinous war against Biafra in the late 1960s
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The devastation it caused, including at least one million dead, is one of the rarely discussed causes of the Boko Haram phenomenon
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The experiences of Algeria and Senegal are in no way unique
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They comprise the story of the modern Muslim world
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: where with the exception of Turkey, Iran and part of the Arabian peninsula most every society from Morocco to Indonesia fell under generations of European rule in the 19th and 20th centuries
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The collective wound of colonialism, its distortion and often destruction of existing pathways to modernity, is for all practical purposes immeasurable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As with a body that takes only seconds to stab or shoot
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the deep wounds of foreign domination and postcolonial dictatorship can take a lifetime to heal properly, if ever
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Chances of healing
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Indeed
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the chances of healing - of some level of local, democratically accountable control of political and economic development - have become even more remote in the era of neoliberal globalisation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which has been rightly seen by many across the region as essentially colonialism dressed in new clothes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: (IMF and World Bank policies strongly resemble those of the international banks that brought Tunisia, Egypt and the Ottoman Empire to bankruptcy, and ultimately foreign control, between 1863 and 1875)
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Radical Islam has today charted a path that mirrors radical capitalism
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: using violence only shocks "us"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because we've managed to make the violence unleashed and supported for so long in our name morally and politically invisible
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The major world powers have long coddled favoured local despots of whatever ideological stripe
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But the strength of the relationships between western governments and the petroleum-rich states of the Arab world, secured by trillions of dollars cycling back and forth between them through oil and arms sales, finance and heavy industry, is historically unprecedented
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Both are rapidly anti-democratic, support the concentration of wealth and power, and draw much of their strength from violence, war and a manageable level of chaos that keep oil prices high and petrodollars recycled via everything from fancy weapons to even fancier real estate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: French reckoning
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Add to that the ongoing and well-documented structural racism against France's large Arab/Muslim and African communities
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which has included mass murder in the streets of Paris and remains "rampant" not merely in the poor suburbs of major cities
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: where concentrated poverty and marginalisation lead so many to crime, drugs, prison and, not uncommonly, to radicalisation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: When newspapers such as the left-leaning Liberation declare that "Europe's leaders are in shock" over the latest attack, their naivety is hard to forgive
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Shocking?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It's no more shocking that some Muslims have become psychotic enough to murder, rape and pillage their way across eastern Nigeria and eastern Paris than it is that France, home of "liberty", "equality", and "fraternity", sells billions of dollars of weapons and otherwise provides political and diplomatic support to countries that practice the polar opposite of all three
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: that the US kills thousands of civilians with drones (and tens of thousands with conventional weapons) that are as merciless as the terrorists they presumably target
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: that Israel kills 1,500 Palestinians with the complete acquiescence of the US and Europe
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: or
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that most every Muslim government condemning the attack on Charlie Hebdo routinely imprisons and tortures artists and activists for far less offensive expression, all with the support of the West
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As the Lebanese cartoonist Karl Sharro (aka Karl reMarks) points out, ultimately the violence against Charlie Hebdo is not about Islam per se
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: it's about a contemporary world system that is particularly adept at grinding down whatever decent values exist in Islam and other faith systems (and in liberal capitalism as well)
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Decades of the combined onslaught of extreme capitalism and extreme religion have shaped a necropolitics of the oppressed
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: that is the mirror image of the necropolitics of local and western governments, and the oppression and violence they've imposed
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Former Charlie Hebdo editor Philippe Val, who lost most of his close friends on Wednesday, lamented that "our country will never be the same", and called on France's Muslim community to "be with us" as they confront the scourge of nihilistic terror
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: to what France can Muslims truly belong?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: which Islam can empower them towards a modernity that provides at least a modicum of "bread, dignity and social justice"
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: to quote the catch phrase of the now distant Arab Spring
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Charlie Hebdo reminds us of anything it is that the arc of blowback can stretch for decades
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: , growing more uncontrollable as the political, economic, social and technological chaos of the contemporary world increases
paragraphs.label: assumption
